So while implementing MVP what is a better approach to prevent circular retention of the references ?
1. attachView, detachView  
or
2. Use WeakReferences ?
How do one set color & ripple effect at same time to buttons in android ?
<@U0G4JHERF>: Use the colored AppCompat Button
any example ?
That shows up only on API 21 and above.
yes
Any solution for API 11 and above.. ?
No ripple effect, just selector states
Thanks! Any example of both combined?
AppCompat takes care of the selector states pre21
if you want to customize the colors of the different states
just make a selector drawable and set colours for the different states
you can google the syntax by yourself :stuck_out_tongue:
ok. Thanks!
Why does google make app developers life so hard.. :D:D
means it’s just a simple Button…
What do you mean?
Well, they do make it easy imo
naah… Developing for iOS is fairly simple..
Some things just don’t work with earlier versions of the system
because there are only six different devices with three different OS versions
not like 9374298379823 screen sizes and 29837923798 devices with 39847298379283 different versions
hmm… still they could do a better job with getting the basic components to work always...
and easily customizable..
They do? It’s a Button. It works fine
Ripple effect is just something new that’s not backwards compatible
What’s the problem with that?
Setting both ripple effect & diff. states of button simultaneously doesn’t seem to be a complicated task to me…
which google has made ...
with so many negative posts on Stack Overflow too..
I see it as a lazy & unpolished release by Google.
The AppCompat Button takes care of that automatically
unless you want your green button to be pink while touched
hmm.. Thanks!

So while implementing MVP what is a better approach to prevent circular retention of the references ?
1. attachView, detachView  
or
2. Use WeakReferences ? 

#repost
for me attaching/detaching has always worked
so I haven’t had to dabble with WeakReferences
I just know that they won’t work for you if you have more than 1 at any point in time.
because it depends on there being only one
<@U0NRVKW8L|greggie> has joined the channel
<@U053PPGDC>: how do you handle config changes with your presenters/views?
badly
:smile:
we detach the activity
some places we hack around and no recreate it
orientation:portrait :troll:
^ so far that’s what im doing for first release
we do have a few of those as well - legacy from when we were working on the fucking sparks
yeah, I've yet to use WeakReferences anywhere near the UI layer

For any views/dialogs/etc I create an associated pojo containing any data needed to present it, on config changes I can easily save store and restore state with it because they all have a load method for that pojo
Idk if thats standard
shit happens when you have longer running tasks, anything else is not a problem
I’ve been able to get away with `android:configChanges="keyboard|keyboardHidden|screenLayout|screenSize|orientation"` on a lot of stuff too haha
Anyone here had a chance working with React Native?
make your presenters live outside the activity lifecycle
also, no to react native
`make your presenters live outside the activity lifecycle` ?
Use none of the approaches ?
none of what

1. attachView, detachView  
or
2. Use WeakReferences ?
that’s orthogonal. you likely want to use attach/detach regardless
Oh

Has anyone done authentication sharing between multiple apps? AccountManager seems like the right solution but it’s my understanding that only one app can define the account and would always have to be installed for the other apps to use it. I’d like to have it so if any of the apps are installed and logged in, all the others will be logged in as well

hello. I want to target Android Froyo+. I know there is an extension pack for Material Design. What I don't want is a slow down on the older systems just to get a pretty front end. I don't plan on requiring much of the material design for core functionality. Is it common to have the business rules and complex algorithms like image processing in one project and then have a front end app for the older models and a front end app for the newer models?
<@U0NSQ8458>: Are you going to target 3rd world countries?
I guess that depends on how you define Brazil. My rollout was US, Brazil
So maybe?
<@U0NSQ8458>: Haha. It was meant as a ‘yes/no’ question. Since you want Froyo as minimal SDK.
Since it’s 0.1% on <http://developer.android.com/about/dashboards/index.html>

text: Why in the world do you want to use froyo as a minsdk?
So I can get the largest market for my app. Though since my app accompanies a paid service, I guess people might have spent money on a newer phone. Though I have an Note 2, which is really dated.
<@U0NSQ8458>: nobody uses froyo
you’ll die developing for it
I’m looking into my Play Store statistics. Since I had a pretty large market in Brazil with one of my apps.
You'd spend too much time making things work for an insignificant amount of the userbase
Doesn’t look like I can select country and version..
If you think that there would be enough devices that would use your app on lower SDK versions, I'd at least use ICS as a minumum
API 15, mind you

I use API 17 for my projects, though some would say use 16, but it really is up to you
I use 15 currently.
The lower the API you choose the more work you might have to do to make everything work the same across API versions

I notice tons of APIs and methods requiring API 16, so I usually stick with API 16 minimum
